total_impedance_ori_txt: R1 and Rc0 connected in series so Rb0=R1+Rc0=2Ohm
R5 and Rb0 connected in parallel so Ra0=R5*Rb0/(R5+Rb0)=1.33Ohm
total_impedance_txt: R1 and R3 connected in series so Rb0=R1+R3=2Ohm
R5 and Rb0 connected in parallel so Ra0=R5*Rb0/(R5+Rb0)=1.33Ohm

total_impedance_ori_txt: R5 and R1 connected in series so Rb1=R5+R1=5Ohm
R3 and Rb1 connected in series so Ra1=R3+Rb1=6Ohm
total_impedance_txt: R5 and R1 connected in series so Rb1=R5+R1=5Ohm
R3 and Rb1 connected in series so Ra1=R3+Rb1=6Ohm

request.text: What is the current on R1?

solution: *** Solution by TINA assisted by AI ***
We have more than one generator so we are using superposition to calculate voltages/currents.
>> Pass1 started ...
>> Gen processing: IS1 ...
At first we calculate the total resistance between the generator nodes (IS1)
R1 and R3 connected in series so Rb0=R1+R3=2Ohm
R5 and Rb0 connected in parallel so Ra0=R5*Rb0/(R5+Rb0)=1.33Ohm
The total resistance is Ra0 = 1.33Ohm
Now we calculate the current on R1

We know that the voltage between IS1 nodes is 1.33V, because the generator current is Igen = 1A and the resistance between the generator nodes is Rtot = 1.33Ohm so the voltage between the generator nodes is Igen*Rtot = 1.33V
All voltage generators have been replaced with a short circuit.
All current generators except for IS1 have been replaced with an open circuit.
(1) The components R5,Rb0 connected in parallel. The voltage on Rb0 is 1.33V because the voltage on Ra0 is 1.33V
(2) The components R1,R3 connected in series.
(2) The voltage between this components starting and ending node is 1.33V.
(2) R1 is in the voltage divider so the voltage on R1 is R1/Rb0*1.33V = 667mV.
(2) The current on R1 is the 'voltage on R1 / R1' = 667mA .
>> Pass2 started ...
>> Gen processing: VS1 ...
At first we calculate the total resistance between the generator nodes (VS1)
R5 and R1 connected in series so Rb1=R5+R1=5Ohm
R3 and Rb1 connected in series so Ra1=R3+Rb1=6Ohm
The total resistance is Ra1 = 6Ohm
Now we calculate the current on R1
We know that the voltage between VS1 nodes is 6V.
All voltage generators except for VS1 have been replaced with a short circuit.
All current generators have been replaced with an open circuit.
(3) The components R3,Rb1 connected in series.
(3) The voltage between this components starting and ending node is 6V.
(3) Rb1 is in the voltage divider so the voltage on Rb1 is Rb1/Ra1*6V = 5V.
(3) The current on Rb1 is the 'voltage on Rb1 / Rb1' = 1A .
(4) The components R5,R1 connected in series.
(4) The voltage between this components starting and ending node is 5V.
(4) R1 is in the voltage divider so the voltage on R1 is R1/Rb1*5V = 1V.
(4) The current on R1 is the 'voltage on R1 / R1' = 1A .
Now we are using superposition to calculate the current on R1
Let's summarize the calculations from the previous section.
When you see subtraction here it means that the original direction reversed.
'current on R1' = 667mA+1A = 1.67A
*** Passed ***: expected: 1.67, got: 1.67
